Goldman agrees sale and leaseback of new London HQ

Goldman Sachs has agreed the £1.2bn sale and leaseback of its new London headquarters with Korea’s National Pension Service in the latest sign of strong demand for property assets in the city.
https://www.ft.com/content/a319a4b4-a622-11e8-8ecf-a7ae1beff35b

Morgan Stanley chooses Frankfurt as post-Brexit EU hub

https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/morgan-stanley-bank-us-frankfurt-eu-hub-headquarters-london-brexit-germany-a7849491.html

The move is expected to double the workforce at its Frankfurt office, which currently houses 200 staff, though the bank may also bulk up additional offices in Paris and Dublin as part of its post-Brexit strategy.

However, sources told the Press Association that London will remain Morgan Stanley's European headquarters.

Morgan Stanley declined to comment.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-27/will-brexit-trigger-an-exodus-of-banks-from-london-quicktake

2. Which businesses might be on the move?
No one really knows, but potentially any front-office or back-office operation with customers in the EU could have to pack up. One likely target is euro clearing, a service to help traders complete transactions safely and at the executed price. The EU is seeking to retake control of a function traditionally handled by London-based clearinghouses: settling derivatives trades denominated in Europe’s common currency, the euro.

3. So when might this start?
It already has. Global banks aren’t waiting around to see what Brexit deal May will strike with her EU counterparts. They have already begun the process of shifting some U.K.-based operations to new or expanded trading hubs inside the EU, and have started recruiting locally for staff.

4. Is there another way?
Not really. Though May has said she wants a “bold and ambitious free-trade agreement” with the EU — one that would safeguard the rights of banks to provide services across the continent — EU regulators have indicated that they won’t tolerate fly-in, fly-out arrangements with bankers commuting from London.

https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/morgan-stanley-bank-us-frankfurt-eu-hub-headquarters-london-brexit-germany-a7849491.html

The move is expected to double the workforce at its Frankfurt office, which currently houses 200 staff, though the bank may also bulk up additional offices in Paris and Dublin as part of its post-Brexit strategy.

However, sources told the Press Association that London will remain Morgan Stanley's European headquarters.

Morgan Stanley declined to comment.
